newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: BHP says money not the point of share issue.
newsitem.headline: BHP says money not the point of share issue.

text.p: Australia's The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (BHP) said on Thursday its plan to make a non-renounceable rights issue was part of a shareholder scheme and was not a capital-raising effort.
BHP spokesman Michael Spencer said immediately after the plan was announced to the Australian Stock Exchange earlier that BHP did not know how much the issue would raise.
"It is not a capital-raising," Spencer told Reuters.
"It's not possible to estimate how many people will take up the scheme," he said, adding that A$636 million would be raised if every shareholder took up their entitlement.
BHP said the number of shares to be issued was not expected to exceed 36.5 million.

BHP told the exchange the purpose of the issue of ordinary shares was to provide eligible shareholders with the opportunity to buy additional small parcels of shares up to a maximum value of A$2,400 per shareholder.
The new shares would rank equally for dividends.
The issue price would be determined over the period May 12 to May 16 inclusive, at a 2.5 percent discount to the weighted average price of shares sold on the market.
The issue follows BHP's decision last year to halve the company's dividend reinvestment and bonus share schemes.
The issue is similar to those offered by other companies to their shareholders, BHP's Spencer said.
"Interest in these sorts of schemes has been expressed at annual general meetings over a period of time and a number of other companies have them," he said.
